populationSmartphones.summary: This calculation estimates what percentage of a city's population would need to charge their smartphones to generate the same carbon emissions as a given flight. It uses data from the US EPA on smartphone charging emissions, as well as UK ONS population data from 2020 for those aged 11 and over, based on the assumption that this age group typically owns smartphones (according to a 2020 Childwise report).
populationSmartphones.calculation:
[14.46 Wh – (22 hours x 0.13 Watts)] x 1 kWh/1,000 Wh = 0.012 kWh/smartphone charged 
0.012 kWh/charge x 1, 562.4 pounds CO2/MWh delivered electricity x 1 MWh/1,000 kWh x 1 metric ton/2,204.6 lbs = 8.22 x 10-6 metric tons CO2/smartphone charged

timeSmartphones.summary: This calculation estimates the carbon emissions generated by charging smartphones, assuming that each person charges their phone once a day. It uses data from the US EPA on smartphone charging emissions.
timeSmartphones.calculation:
[14.46 Wh – (22 hours x 0.13 Watts)] x 1 kWh = 0.012 kWh/smartphone charged 
0.012 kWh/charge x 1, 562.4 pounds CO2/MWh delivered electricity x 1 MWh x 1 metric ton/2,204.6 lbs = 8.22 x 10-6 metric tons CO2/smartphone charged

lightbulbs.summary: This calculation estimates how long an LED or CFL lightbulb would need to be left on to generate the same carbon emissions as a given flight. It uses data from the Ember environmental think tank on the UK's carbon intensity from generating electricity and assumes an average wattage of 13.5W for LED or CFL lightbulbs.
lightbulbs.calculation:
13.5W (average LED/CFL bulb) x 24 = 0.324kWh 
 0.324kWh x 236g CO₂e/kWh (UK carbon intensity) = 0.076kg CO₂e/day

commutes.summary: This calculation estimates the carbon emissions from daily commutes, assuming an approximate calculation of 2.3kg CO₂e per litre of petrol (based on the combustion of hydrocarbons), an average car fuel consumption of 11.5 miles per litre from GOV.UK data, and an ONS data-supported average commute distance of 7 miles in the UK.
